 It is not at all surprising in view of the wide and growing influence of these religions that when the disciples in Antioch and elsewhere preached a crucified and risen Jesus they should be regarded as the heralds of another mystery religion, and that Jesus himself should be taken for the divine Lord of the cult through whose death and resurrection salvation was to be had.
 
 It is at this point that we are able to see why knowledge of these cults is important for any serious New Testament study. That there were striking similarities between the developing church and these religions cannot be denied. Even Christian apologist had to admit that fact.  This is not to say that a Saint Paul or a Saint John sat down and copied these views verbatim. In the context of gays and Christianity, it's worth recalling the findings of a recent survey by the Christian Barna Group:
 
 A New Generation Expresses its Skepticism and Frustration with Christianity
 
 
The study shows that 16- to 29-year-olds exhibit a greater degree of criticism toward Christianity than did previous generations when they were at the same stage of life. In fact, in just a decade, many of the Barna measures of the Christian image have shifted substantially downward, fueled in part by a growing sense of disengagement and disillusionment among young people. For instance, a decade ago the vast majority of Americans outside the Christian faith, including young people, felt favorably toward Christianity's role in society. Currently, however, just 16% of non-Christians in their late teens and twenties said they have a "good impression" of Christianity.

 
 It seems that a lot of this negative impression is driven by the perception of Christian evangelicals and fundamentalists. Anti-homosexuality is high on the list of negative traits:
 
 
Interestingly, the study discovered a new image that has steadily grown in prominence over the last decade. Today, the most common perception is that present-day Christianity is "anti-homosexual." Overall, 91% of young non-Christians and 80% of young churchgoers say this phrase describes Christianity. As the research probed this perception, non-Christians and Christians explained that beyond their recognition that Christians oppose homosexuality, they believe that Christians show excessive contempt and unloving attitudes towards gays and lesbians. One of the most frequent criticisms of young Christians was that they believe the church has made homosexuality a "bigger sin" than anything else. Moreover, they claim that the church has not helped them apply the biblical teaching on homosexuality to their friendships with gays and lesbians.

 
 Even young Christians are seeing Christianity as being defined by anti-homosexuality! It's no wonder non-Christians, and especially gays, are developing an essentially negative view of this religion. Before Jim jumps down my throat again for generalising, I realise this doesn't apply to all Christians, and many Christians don't define themselves by what they are against, but what has Christianity become if this is a dominant perception of it? Even among younger Christians?
 
 When people have come to regard the phrase "Christian love" as a satirical oxymoron, I think that's a sign that much of Christianity has left the path of love, if, indeed, it was ever on it. Many Christians are the fine, upstanding Desmond Tutu sort of Christians it is good to have at your side at the barricades, but many others are the judgmental sort who would as soon knife you in the back.

Homosexuality, for good or ill, has become one of the defining issues for Christianity in this generation. The prospective schism of the Anglican church is a symptom of this. Christians will be judged by their peers on where they stand on it.

 
 If this is true, it is unfortunate because it is based on a wrong perception, for the most part, IMO. As someone who has been involved in Christianity for a very long time, my experience is that most Christians, including most pastors, don't really address the issue that much at all. If it is a defining issue, it is more because of outside opponents of Christians than Christians themselves in general. I've never once heard a sermon on the subject of gay relations being sinful, and I've been in a lot of churches, some of them fundamentalist. In the grand scheme of things, other matters are talked about far more in Christian circles. For instance, one of the things I've heard levied against Christians as criticism is that they oppose gays marrying more than they do divorce, but this is just not true--I've heard WAAAAY teaching and preaching against divorce than gays getting married. Certainly the issue of gays marrying has been divisive in some places (such as the Anglican church example), but the many people for which it seems to be defining are those who are already out to see something bad in the religion. Again, as in many cases, this all goes back to the fact that Christians are not a monolithic group of one mindset; they do not sign anything; there is no governing body for all Christians, and there is little that can ever be said about the whole religion that is all-inclusive. I think, honestly, that gay pride proponents probably spend a lot more time thinking about the negative things from the religion and the Bible over this than do most Christians themselves. 
 
 Part of the problem is the ol' catch-22 that those who say insipid things tend to make the news more, and as a result the relatively few Christian leaders who are truly on a mission against gays are in the news more than the scores who aren't, and it plays right into the hands of those who are looking for something over which to berate religion already. And people on the fence who aren't willing to delve deeper for a more accurate look may sometimes get their perceptions colored about the whole religion because of a relatively few leaders who happen to be in the spotlight.
 
 I think over time, this issue will stabilize. I think it will play out a lot like the prohibition/temperance movement of the 20th century. Anti-gay Christians will, I think, eventually limit their objections to a more 'non-policy-related' arena that only focuses on the moralistic issue. From my perspective, it never was as much a pet issue in Christianity that critics think it is (or portray it as), and it will become even less so over time. FWIW, Christianity is hardly in any danger whatsoever from this perception out there. It has thrived under other less-than-accurate social perceptions about it in the past. It's not going to go away; religion is a fact of life in our society. Gay rights will come more quickly by people trying to build bridges to religion, rather than opposing it and just wishing it would go away. (For instance, helping religious people see that gays aren't bad people, for instance.)

Certainly the issue of gays marrying has been divisive in some places (such as the Anglican church example), but the many people for which it seems to be defining are those who are already out to see something bad in the religion. Again, as in many cases, this all goes back to the fact that Christians are not a monolithic group of one mindset; they do not sign anything; there is no governing body for all Christians, and there is little that can ever be said about the whole religion that is all-inclusive. I think, honestly, that gay pride proponents probably spend a lot more time thinking about the negative things from the religion and the Bible over this than do most Christians themselves.

It's true Christians aren't a monolithic group -- I have been at pains to acknowledge that, heaping praise on Christians such as Tutu and Soulforce. But if we spend an inordinate amount of time worrying about the negative aspects of Christianity, it's because Christians do the same.

 I used to attend the Oakhurst Baptist Church in Decatur, GA, just outside Atlanta. The church has long been intentionally inter-racial. However, this church ran into trouble with the Georgia Baptist Convention a few years ago over its acceptance of gay people. This story is from a Baptist publication from 2001. I am including a brief excerpt of the story in blue. The material in blue is quoted from the website. Go to the link to read the whole thing: 
 
 http://www.baptist2baptist.net/b2barticle.asp?ID=150
 
 Georgia Baptist Convention withdraws Atlanta Baptist Association funding 
 by Staff
 March 14, 2001 
 
 ATLANTA (BP)--The Georgia Baptist Convention's executive committee voted unanimously March 13 to defund the Atlanta Baptist Association in response to the association's failure to expel two pro-homosexual congregations from its membership. 
 
 The Atlanta association will lose $47,000 in special project money and $113,000, matched by the Southern Baptist Convention to fund 16 Atlanta-area missionaries. The association's annual budget is about $750,000.... 
 The GBC's move comes one day after an attempt to expel from the Atlanta Baptist Association two churches that affirm homosexuality came up short, when messengers to the 93rd annual meeting of the association failed to reach a two-thirds majority. 
 
 As a result, Oakhurst Baptist Church and Virginia-Highland Baptist Church will remain affiliated with the 143 congregations and missions of the association. However, both churches could face future disciplinary action from the association after messengers voted to send the issue back to the ABA's membership committee for disciplinary review. 
 
 Still, that may not be enough for a number of conservative Baptist churches that have already announced their intentions of pulling out of the association....

 It's not merely "tolerance" I am after -- that is the minimal, non-negotiable position of compromise. It's moral acceptance I'm looking for. I realise that there will be many I cannot get it from, but from my perspective, I have major ethical problems with their attitudes. 
 
 
what bothers me is the obsession with this issue to the detriment of far more serious issues of poverty and injustice about which the church should be concerned. Where is the push from American churches to guarantee healthcare for everyone? Where is the pressure from American churches for US drug companies to lower their prices, particularly on HIV/AIDS medication?

 
 From what I've read of Tutu, he is at least concerned by what the homosexuality issue is smothering as by its own injustice. It does distract attention from more -- I almost said important issues, but I think more general is the more apt adjective. There is no point in expending resources and energy promoting injustice to gay people, when one could be fighting it on other fronts.
jyoshu

Because their religion tells them too. Religion poisons everything.

 
 Ironic that you would say that after being given an example of someone it didn't poison: the Lutheran minister who apparently sees no conflict between being gay and her faith. As well as the Soulforce examples. Nor did it poison Desmund Tutu, as Lesz used in example earlier. You need to stop generalising, and I will continue to point out examples where your all-encompassing statements are quite simply wrong, when you do so.
jyoshu

 Only if you take one example and apply it to every possible case.
